ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a live virtual class every day that was organized like a seminar due to the class size.
None
Meeting in small groups outside of class for project work and study
I dont think so.
We also participated in virtual TA sessions.
n/a

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to further develop my Korean language skills. While we did not have any official exams, we were able to apply our understanding of the course content through a variety of projects including KDramas, CookBang, skits, interviews, and PSA documentaries.
I improved my Korean skills a lot and got to practice through many projects assigned by Lee seonsaengnim.

I continued to learn more about the Korean language, both written and spoken. I found that this level was less focused on absorbing a ton of vocab like previous classes were, but more focused on learning grammar and testing it out. There was more emphasis on being able to speak fluidly and hold a conversation, as well as more projects to learn independently.
How to speak Korean in a more versed manner
Developed my Korean language skills, particularly speaking and listening comprehension which was a huge focus in the class.
Better ability to naturally use the Korean language in speaking and writing for more fluid conversation.

I improved my pronunciation / speaking skills a lot, especially when it comes to natural communication in dialogue. I was also able to work with my fellow classmates to make a lot of cool projects related to Korean culture.
Since our course was virtual, my professor wanted to focus more on our oral skills and she wanted us to be able to speak fluently to each other. This helped to improve my oral skills in the language.
We learned  a lot of new grammar that would be useful in everyday conversation. Also we explored many aspects of Korean culture with very fun assignment.

I was significantly able to improve fluent speaking in Korean as well as learn a bevy of conversational grammar structures. I was able to write and apply Korean in a variety of skits, presentations, and creative writing assignments.
How to speak and write in Korean
I greatly developed my korean skills and mainly my speaking skills when taking this class.
The focus of this course, in relation to previous Korean courses, was on writing and grammar. Those skills advanced faster than others like speaking and vocabulary.
I improved my level of Korean, specifically by learning more advanced grammar structures and by practicing colloquial speech.
I improved my knowledge of Korean grammar, vocabulary, and speaking through various projects and in class activities

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: The course required you to be constantly engaged. Staying on top of the content was important in successfully completing the assignments.  I liked how we had open discussions in Korean in class.
This course is amazing and Lee seonsaengnim is super helpful and welcoming. I don't have any suggestions for improvements.

Strengths: The biggest strength for me was my professor. Lee SSN is a delight, as always. She is incredible at making class engaging and fun I was practically never stressed about this class despite having class, homework, and projects every day. She is so encouraging and really makes you want to become a better Korean speaker. Although this has been a very difficult semester and I struggle to learn as much virtually as I would in person, I still feel that I have made progress and am still excited about the Korean language. 

Weaknesses: This is very nitpicky, I seriously thought this was a great class, but here goes: Although I absolutely loved having a projects-based class rather than exams, I think the occasional low-stakes quiz would be good to learn some new words or force myself to really internalize and memorize the new grammar structures (of which there were a lot!). I think even maybe a kahoot with this kind of stuff would be fun and use people's competitive nature to their own advantage when it comes to learning.

This course is really well-balanced; there are a lot of assignments and work for the different skill areas (speaking, reading, writing, etc.) and Professor Lee is incredibly supportive and makes you feel like you are capable of more than you may believe you are initially.

Strengths: amazing, thoughtful, kind professor who really cares about each student; engaged students; fun and interesting projects
Weaknesses: none!
Language classes are always better in-person but Lee really made it work! Honestly shes the biggest strength of the course.

This course was taught extremely well in terms of one-on-one student engagement (even in lecture settings) and the usage of breakout rooms to continue language practice. Additionally the language table also allowed us to have a space to practice and clarify topics.
It's awesome! Issn is the best teacher ever

This course, although more difficult due to it being a language course taken virtually, was still always engaging. The weaknesses only are due to it being difficult to properly hear pronunciation due to virtual lessons. Still, it was overall a very strong class with an amazing professor.

Given the circumstances of this semester, the course was well-suited to engaging students virtually. In particular, the focus on projects with drafts and feedback was helpful for making and maintaining progress.
Our professor really took into account the circumstances around us and she curated the class to help us adjust to everything while still learning what we needed.

Strengths: Lee ssn! Professor Lee is incredibly kind and encouraging, and she explains things very clearly. Professor Lee truly cares about her students and their progress, and she creates an open class environment. Weaknesses: The only weakness of the course was the pacing of larger assignments; sometimes we would have two or three large assignments in a row and then a week or two without any. I would have preferred spacing them out more evenly.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the use of breakout rooms. It allowed us to have more personal conversations where we could participate more than if we were in the full section.

I think taking away the testing aspect was super great since it gave us less pressure and I felt more encouraged to learn. I liked doing a lot of projects since they were fun and I felt like I learned a lot at the same time.
I think having more breakout rooms was a great way of keeping us engaged, and the projects as well. I thought Lee SSN adapted incredibly well to virtual teaching.
Of course it would have been great to have language be taught in person, but i think Professor Lee-Smith did an amazing job on zoom and made sure to have everyone participate.
I really liked the using presentations. It makes the lesson easy to understand and share.
All succeeded

Having more project based Korean assignments were very helpful since I had taken Korean the previous semester online with online tests that were very difficult due to not properly hearing pronunciation over the in-class test, so having more emphasis on recorded speaking assignments and projects were very helpful.

The focus on projects, both for writing and presentation, were the most useful for making progress both in class and as homework. Use of breakout rooms to practice was also helpful. It might be an improvement to randomize group members for projects, but there are definitely some in the class who enjoyed working with the same people repeatedly.

Tests were removed and we only had projects and in class discussions in breakout rooms. They honestly helped remove a source of stress and everyone was still able to progress and learn throughout the class. The podcasts we did were especially helpful because it was done with peers and friends in the class and helped improve listening and speaking comprehension.

I liked that we often used breakout rooms and took advantage of the online format by doing watching lots of videos or doing online exercises. I wish that we could have done more reading comprehension practice, though, since it felt like we focused mostly on speaking, listening, and writing.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in taking Korean as a language for the first time, I believe you must take L1 and L2 before taking this course. Even though taking three semesters of language is required, I really enjoyed this class and Professor Lee-Smith is amazing.
Yes, this course really helps you learn if you want to get better at Korean.
Absolutely! Take this class. You won't regret it.
Definitely take it if Professor Lee is teaching it. Amazing and fulfilling experience.

I would most definitely recommend this course. Professor Lee is one of the few professors who teaches beyond the scope of the class as per its syllabus, but it doesnt feel like shes cramming information it - it simply follows a logical flow of development. Professor Lee fixes your mistakes without chastising or scolding you, as she realizes mistakes are as much a part of learning a language as speaking the language. Its a very warm and positive environment, and its made my time at Yale exponentially better.
Yes, of course! It was so much fun, and Professor Lee-Smith is an absolutely stellar instructor for Korean.

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. I felt that my professor was prepared to teach in a virtual format, and she provided fun projects and started insightful discussions in class.
I would definitely recommend this course! The classwork is highly engaging, creative, and fun. The course is highly constructive and learning is very enjoyable.
Absolutely. Issn best teacher at Yale!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The professor was amazing and the class itself really did improve my Korean speaking, reading, and understanding skills. Not only that but the professor always kept the class engaging and really focused on teaching Korean that we would really encounter currently, such as including pandemic vocabulary and grammar as well as introducing online podcast and video assignments.
Absolutely, though their experience will vary if they have another instructor!
Yes! Specifically with this professor!!
Yes! It's a great course that will help you improve your Korean!
Yes, I would definitely recommend you take this course with this professor. She is an amazing professor and will adjust the curriculum to the needs of the students.
